chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
On the Sincerity and Usefulness of the New Edition of the Works of Saint Jerome, and on the Ignorance and Malevolence in the Jerome Questions by Jean Le Clerc.

Recently, several works by Jean Le Clerc, both critical and miscellaneous, have come to light. These works often contain discussions that are insulting to scholars and burdensome to wise readers.

Early in this century, the same author's Jerome Questions were published. In these, he unleashed all his malice, anger, and hatred against us and our new edition of Saint Jerome.

Unlike other critics, Clerc did not just want to criticize the specifics or letters of our edition. Instead, he aimed to completely overthrow it and, if possible, erase the memory of the author from history.

The extent to which he sought to trouble the Martian with his works is evident from the warning prefixed to the Jerome Questions. In this, he hoped to incite the envy of all scholars, even stirring singular hatred among my dearest colleagues against me.

He even went so far as to flatter, invoking the wisdom and authority of my superiors, so that I might ultimately be prohibited from working on the Jerome edition. If Clerc had gained their assent, I would have been the most miserable of editors and writers of this time.

As I ponder the cause of such intense anger, I suspect it is simply my defense of Jerome and the tribute I have paid to his learning. This is not a wild guess, as Clerc himself agrees with me, beginning his Question 7 by saying: "We have already said that we would have had no controversy with Martian if he had given moderate praise to Jerome."

Therefore, the root of this is that I have exalted Jerome with praises and defended his works against Clerc's reproaches. But let's hear the accuser himself present the arguments of my supposed crime.
chunks.original_latin:
De sinceritate et utilitate editionis novae Operum S. Hieronymi,
deque imperitia ac malevolentia Quaestionum Hieronymianarum
Joannis Clerici. Dudum e tenebris prodierant in lucem opuscula haud
pauca Joannis Clerici tam critica quam miscellanea, ubi
saepius occurrunt disceptationes viris doctis contumeliosae,
atque sapienti lectori graves et molestae: saeculo autem
praesenti ineunte prodierunt ejusdem auctoris Quaestiones
Hieronymianae in quibus totum pectoris virus, iram scilicet
et odium effudit in nos nostramque novam editionem
 S. Hieronymi. Neque vero caeterorum criticorum morem
secutus, eventilare voluit apices solummodo Clericus noster,
litterasve calumniari editionis nostrae; sed eam evertere
funditus, auctorisque memoriam e vivis tollere si potuisset. Quantum enim Martianaeum opera sua sollicitari studuerit,
testis est admonitio praefixa Quaestionibus Hieronymianis,
qua litteratorum omnium invidiam, immo charissimorum
sodalium in me singulare odium sese concitaturum speravit:
quinetiam praepositorum meorum prudentiam et
auctoritatem interponere blandiendo curavit, ut sic tandem
editione Hieronymiana mihi interdiceretur. Et sane si
Clerico nostri praebuissent assensum, prorsus nihil abfuisset,
quin essem miserrimus omnium editorum et scriptorum
hujus temporis. Tantarum autem irarum dum causam inspicio, non aliam
suspicor praeter susceptam Hieronymi defensionem, et eruditionis
ejusdem exornatum a me tropaeum. Nec magnus
sum in ea re opinator, cum Clericus ipse mecum consentiat,
suam Quaestionem 7 ita exorsus: Jam diximus nullam
nobis controversiam futuram fuisse cum Martianaeo, si
modicas laudes in Hieronymum contulisset. Capitis itaque
causa mihi est quod, Hieronymum ad coelum laudibus levaverim,
et ejus opuscula contra Clericos objurgatores amaverim
 defensitare. Sed audiamus oratorem ipsum criminosum
argumenta dicentem criminis mei.
